title: Tockholes Walks

images.caption: The original St Stephen's School in Tockholes village, built in 1834

images.title: Allan Friswell / Autumn view at Roddlesworth Reservoir
images.caption: Autumn view at Roddlesworth Reservoir

images.title: Alexander P Kapp / Royal Arms, Tockholes
images.caption: Royal Arms, Tockholes. Located next to the visitor centre the pub is a nice place for rest and refreshment after your exercise.

images.title: Gary Rogers / Waterfall on stream above Roddlesworth reservoir
images.caption: Waterfall on stream above Roddlesworth reservoir

images.title: John Darch / Tockholes No 2 Plantation
images.caption: Tockholes No 2 Plantation. An autumnal carpet of beech leaves on the path.

images.title: Mr T / Witton Weavers Way on Darwen Hill
images.caption: Witton Weavers Way on Darwen Hill. Taken from another of the many tracks that criss-cross the moor. Darwen or Jubilee tower on the horizon.

images.title: ALAN SOUTHWORTH / Darwen or Jubilee tower.
images.caption: Darwen or Jubilee tower. The tower, built to celebrate Queen Victoria's diamond jubilee. The first sod was laid in 1897 and the official opening was 1898. From the top viewing platform can be seen the peaks of the Yorkshire dales, the lakeland and Welsh mountains, and west to the Irish sea.

images.title: Gordon Griffiths / Bold Venture Park Pool
images.caption: Bold Venture Park Pool. The Pool near Manor Road, Darwen.

description: This area in the West Pennine Moors is a popular place for walkers with woodland trails, reservoirs and a fantastic hill climbs to try. This circular route visits some of the highlights of the area including the Tockholes Woodland Plantation, Roddlesworth Reservoir, the Darwen Tower and Bold Venture Park. The walk starts from the Roddlesworth Information Centre on Tockholes Road where there is a good sized car park. From here you can pick up a nature trail heading north west through the Tockholes Number 2 Plantation to Roddlesworth Reservoir. The route then picks up the Witton Weavers Way and follows the waymarked trail along the reservoir before turning north to visit Tockholes village. You then head south east to pass Earnsdale Reservoir and Sunnyhurst Reservoir. Here you turn south to enjoy a climb to iconic Darwen Tower.  The tower was built in the late 19th century to commemorate Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee. There's excellent views over the surrounding moors from this elevated spot. The route then descends to the east to pay a visit to Bold Venture Park. This pretty park on the outskirts of Darwen includes peaceful woodland trails and ponds. After exploring the park the route then heads west across Darwen Moor to return to the visitor centre and the car park.
